body: @paulcastro going to take care of this when he updates to swift 3.1

FYI I rebased this and fixed a missing slash:

```
- && apt-get -y install --fix-missing python-gevent python-flask
+ && apt-get -y install --fix-missing python-gevent python-flask \
```

one test fails
![screen shot 2017-04-03 at 2 58 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4959922/24626184/70e27260-187e-11e7-9afd-78f4a4c438d6.png)

it's because of this error:
```
"/swift3Action/spm-build/.build/release/Action: error while loading shared libraries: libswiftCore.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory" was not empty (SwiftActionContainerTests.scala:235)
```

@paulcastro FYI if it's helpful.
@csantanapr it might be worth explaining and documenting why the python:default mode is python:2 not python:3 (as a result of @2094) - I suspect that's @cclauss' concern.

oh, yes
If initial python support was done with python 3 instead of python 2, then having now default 3 would be fine.

But now we have users that written python 2 actions and have them in the system and using kind default, switching to python 3 as the default will cause them pain as there is high chance their code braking running on python 3 if they re-create/teardown-redeploy those actions.

So for now leaving python:2 as default and making clear in docs and other means to tell folks that now python 3 is available, that is recommended by the python community that python 3 is  a better choice and that we are evaluating the option of making python 3 the default, so best practice and to protect your code be explicit which python you want when you create or update your action use python:2 and python:3 not default.
Yeah I rebase and added a slash on branch @paulcastro https://github.com/csantanapr/openwhisk/commit/91555aaaa3c3b416af56c2415d9fc984c2890ebb

for posterity, let me add:

`--kind python` continues to mean `python:2`.
we added explicit kind options for `python:2` and `python:3` (via #1903).
note that we did not have `python:default` until last week in master, so i don't think this is an issue (namely changing default to mean 2 vs 3).

instead, the real wrinkle is/was with respect to what kind does the CLI assume when creating python actions and no explicit kind is specified. in #1903, this was changed from `python` (meaning `python:2`) to `python: default`.

I favored the more focused change of making that `python:2` and leaving `python:default` to mean `python:3`. but this would have been inconsistent with stripping all kinds from the CLI and using only `family:default` instead.
It will be useful to document the plan to change/bump the default from 2 to 3, and get it rolling.

Agreed.  When Python 3 was released, the current version of Java was 6.0 and Swift and Node were not even released.  Somehow OW defaults to Java 8 (~3 years old), Swift 3 (~6 months old), and Nodejs 6 (~6 months old) but does not default to a nine year old version of Python.

@csantanapr i'll re-open with the action item being: let's make python:default mean python:3.
will you drive this? if not, can you enumerate the steps you'd like to see done so someone can drive it?

@rabbah I would like someone more verse in python than me to drive this.
- [ ] Blog post "OW loves python 3 you should also" (tell folks about python 3, and about pinning)
- [ ] Discuss in dev list, get feedback from users on slack, when should the date be to allow folks using python 2 to migrate their code to python 3 or pinned to python:2.  1 month?, 2 months?, 3 months?
- [ ] Update Docs with section under python "Pinned to python:2 or python:3, python:default will switch from 2 to 3 on date x"

What you think @rabbah can you drive this, anything else to add to the list?
Yes.  I will take that action.

The new Watson SDK is not backward compatible with the old one.  I've got a [branch](https://github.com/paulcastro/openwhisk/tree/issue_2079) that upgrades to Swift 3.1 and uses the newest KituraNet and the Watson SDK.  I had to change the tests to make it work.  

I held off making a PR for this because there was some discussion about the right way to introduce new versions as kind types vs when to deprecate the old version.

@jeremiaswerner this will need a blue companion - want to take it?

I have few experience on CloudFoundry, and didn`t try to run OW on it.
But I have experience on running OW with Swarm.
You may refer to it.

Since CloudFoundry is PaaS, I guess it might provide docker in a similar way with Swarm.

In Swarm, it provides a single docker endpoint which accepts docker run request.
It will deploy a container on one of(few of) its agent machines.
Scheduling is managed by swarm manager.
So user can only care about a single docker endpoint to run container on docker cluster.

But in OpenWhisk, it is deployed via ansible which requires ssh access to host machine.
And Openwhisk Invoker communicates with local docker engine.
It requires docker unix socket as well as volume mapping of docker RootDir.
To find out the RootDir of docker, it uses docker remote api.
(Docker remote api is used in other parts also)

To sum up,

1. SSH access on docker host
2. Remote docker api should be enabled.
3. Access on host(volume mapping of docker RootDir)

There could be more things to consider, but in my case(Swarm), it was working with those things.
I am not sure these are allowed in CloudFoundry.

I hope it helps you.

And for the next time, you may want to join [slack](http://slack.openwhisk.org/) or subscribe mailing list: dev@openwhisk.incubator.apache.org.

PR https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2114

New behaviour:

`wsk action invoke <name> --result`
invokes the action implicit as blocking invocation.
If --result is specified, --blocking can be omitted.

Specifying --blocking and --result still works.
PG1#1365 is green.

@paulcastro thanks for attending to this PR. Today, the _old_ Watson package https://github.com/IBM-Swift/swift-watson-sdk is available again such that Travis and other builds work again.

If said package should be unavailable _again_ - either due to an outage or due to intentional removal -, we need to take immediate action to enable builds.
@vherrin - fyi

There is a more up-to-date sdk with all of the Watson services available at this location below.  The IBM-Swift SDK was a stopgap for server side linux but the Watson Developer Cloud Swift SDK now has linux support.  Please let me know if you have issue or concerns with this information

https://github.com/watson-developer-cloud/swift-sdk

I installed Openwhisk two weeks ago and I'm still not seeing the alarms package.  I downloaded the openwhisk-package-alarms and did the installCatalog.sh but I keep getting errors.  How do I get the /whisk.system/alarms package for open whisk to work?

@mimy2001 see this issue: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-package-alarms/issues/50

the alarm (and cloudant) package is not installed as part of the catalog, you have to do it explicitly.
@jeremiaswerner - Would you kindly review/merge?
When will it be a part of the catalog?

@mdeuser I suspect there's a race in these tests actually - not convinced the bump will help.
I recall finding at least one but don't think it was fixed/merged. I'll post an update after I verify what I just said.

@rabbah - Would the race condition result in a timeout or a message conflict?  PG3 builds #500, #494, and #487 all passed the test, but with elapsed times very close to exceeding the current timeout value.  I did see another failure in PG3 #474 in which all tests failed... that could be due to messages spilling over into the follow-on kafka tests.  Perhaps both issues are at play?

The proper fix in this case would be to properly measure the size of the activation and deny a result which is too large? I suspect this is an error because we allow up to 1MB of response size (and 1MB in Kafka) but the activation JSON is response size + metadata, which can grow > 1MB?
The issue was caused by exactly what you pointed out: the result is 1MB but with metadata added it's over the Kafka limit. That's the system's fault.
Note however that by increasing the active ack to 60s we basically dropped the recovery for a failed Kafka consumer on the controller side.

Related to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/2063.

With the latest simplifications of action "kinds", I expect we can add a new kind eg `nodejs:6-dashb` as a deployment configuration. This will intersect with work that @csantanapr has started to publish runtime images to dockerhub. I imagine that we can setup individual repos for various runtimes, push them to dockerhub, and point the [runtime manifest](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1980/files#diff-2d879ae862e88c1fe4c4e19affaeffddR38) at these to extend the runtime support in a particular deployment.

What's the intended flow in the end for our CLI story? How will we release new versions of the CLI?
Please add me as a reviewer, @pritidesai.

@pritidesai, please do not build the CLI using Ansible. Ansible should pull down the binaries that are already built from the latests Git release. Also, there is no need to pull down the CLI source code here.

@dubeejw Do we plan to download the binaries directly from the release? I thought we should build them from the latest code. At least we should have an option to either build from code or download directly.
@houshengbo, every time new code is pushed to the CLI repo new binaries will be generated and posted to the git release page. Therefore, OpenWhisk will always download the latest CLI.

@markusthoemmes The go cli is starting its journey to become a separate repo: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/. This repo has already hosted the latest cli and able to build automatically if we add a new tag to the master branch.
@pritidesai - Same basic comment as above.  Will CLI builds from the new repo be responsible for publishing the CLI binaries ?
@mdeuser, @csantanapr
@dubeejw If we need to build the binary for every commit, how do we deal with the old binary built from old commits? Keep them all or overwrite them? How do we manage the major version?
Perhaps adding some of this summary information to the `activation list` output would be useful (i.e. response status, execution start/duration)
